data.title: Diseases of Celery
data.meta_description: Celery (Apium graveolens L. var. dulce) is an important vegetable grown for both the fresh and processing markets. Crop production of celery is impacted by various diseases that decrease production, quality of petioles, and overall plant health. Foliar diseases caused by both fungi and bacteria are important. Early blight (Cercospora apii) and late blight (Septoria apiicola) are the most impactful fungal foliar diseases. Bacterial foliar diseases caused by Pseudomonas spp. also impact production. Viral diseases also occur. Several pathogens cause diseases that decrease yield through petiole lesions including bacterial soft rot (Pectobacterium carotovorum subsp. carotovorum) and crater rot (Rhizoctonia solani). Soilborne pathogens Pythium spp., Rhizoctonia solani, and Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. apii cause damping-off in seedlings and young greenhouse transplants. Disease management strategies vary based on the production system and the diseases involved. Consideration of cultural practices, chemical and biological controls, and resistant cultivars is important in disease management.
data.text:
Abstract

Celery (Apium graveolens L. var. dulce) is an important vegetable grown for both the fresh and processing markets. Crop production of celery is impacted by various diseases that decrease production, quality of petioles, and overall plant health. Foliar diseases caused by both fungi and bacteria are important. Early blight (Cercospora apii) and late blight (Septoria apiicola) are the most impactful fungal foliar diseases. Bacterial foliar diseases caused by Pseudomonas spp. also impact production. Viral diseases also occur. Several pathogens cause diseases that decrease yield through petiole lesions including bacterial soft rot (Pectobacterium carotovorum subsp. carotovorum) and crater rot (Rhizoctonia solani). Soilborne pathogens Pythium spp., Rhizoctonia solani, and Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. apii cause damping-off in seedlings and young greenhouse transplants. Disease management strategies vary based on the production system and the diseases involved. Consideration of cultural practices, chemical and biological controls, and resistant cultivars is important in disease management.
